video_title: Is this feature worth $2400?  The Snapmaker 2.0 Rotary
comment_text:
10:18  Yeah, Enclosure (Which imo is kind of required for the laser) + Rotary + Main Machine is quite expensive.

I donâ€™t know where i stand on it.  From what Iâ€™ve seen itâ€™s a good machine.  I also love the modular design, and sealed parts with rugged cables.

My main complaint is that itâ€™s not open source, granted they have fears of copycats i guess?  Maybe they could do something like open source the last generation each time they make a new one?

Iâ€™m excited to see the one in itâ€™s printing, because a locked down extruder/nozzle ecosystem is a concern i have not knowing much about this.

Also selling â€œtoolplatesâ€ so you could make a drag knife (or knife + servos for turning with the cut), or marker, or even EDM module would be really cool.  I think one channel has made their own pen  holder for the snapmaker.  Open Sourcing the standard could help toolhead development too.

I guess in conclusion if they could open source it, and/or get the cost of the rotary+enclosure+machine down to maybe 1,000-1,500 USD or so it would be top tier of â€œfirst 3d printerâ€ category, not just â€œbest all in one machineâ€!  But as of now that all in one aspect is itâ€™s only real plus i guess.

They will not mill metals without modifcations... but if you have the right drills you can do a lot with wood or some polyuerathane foam stuff.

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text: "15 watt" laser? This is true. The laser manufacturers are taking the idea of running electronics at a lower power to lengthen their lives. GE used to do that with incandescent lifebulbs - they would manufacture the bulbs to run at 130v AC so that when we used them at normal household voltage (110-120) the bulbs would last a lot longer than typical bulbs. So NEJE is doing the same with their modules - building them with 15 watt, but driving them to produce 10.5 -11 watt output. So even if you run them at 100% for long projects, the laser will still continue to produce full power and have a decent lifespan. I have been reading how a few laser users are finding out that their lesser well-designed lasers would die soon after a project that required their lasers to run at 100% for an extended period of time. This is why NEJE, Atomstack and  other laser manufacturers are doing this "underpowering" their laser modules to extend their lives. They use 7.5 watt laser diodes and only force them to deliver 5 Watts. The dual diodes are 7.5 diodes x2, each powered to produce about 5.5 Watts each to result in a 10-12 watt laser, depending on the manufacturer. These NEW modules are typically rated with 20, 000 hour life spans.

video_title: How Good is this Thing? Snapmaker 2.0 Laser Module Review
comment_text:
Iâ€™ve been using my T250 for about a month now. Iâ€™ve found it to be a way better printer than my Ender 3 V2, easy to set up, easy to calibrate and much more even bed heating. Iâ€™ve found it way easier to get consistent layering and I havenâ€™t had a print come loose yet. Once you get the work flow down swapping between modes is about 5 minutes work. Laser works well for engraving and cuts 2mm birch,  it itâ€™s slow. Luban works well very well if youâ€™re just doing something straight forward. 

My assessment, itâ€™s much easier to get started, get making and get consistent results with this than my Ender. I enjoy using the snapmaker and feel like I get to focus on the project not the machine. My first month with the ender was an endless series of failed prints, great learning experience but at times quite discouraging. First time I booted up the SM, it auto calibrated, I dropped the print head 0.5mm, hit print and got a perfect print of a model I was still failing to get on the Ender after a half dozen attempts.

For the hardcore 3D printers out there perhaps the bang for the buck is low, for the rest of us this is great

video_title: How Good is this Thing? Snapmaker 2.0 Laser Module Review
comment_text: been using it for over a year, I upgraded the laser since it really was the weak point and works great. Is sturdy, elegant and just works, I use cura, ligthburn and fusion 360 because luban is very basic. I upgraded the power supply and linear modules and its really silent now. I also 3d printed accessories  for pen (for plotter art) and a drag knife for cutting vinyl. No complaints here. A lot of the issues I see people complaining are more about all the things you need to know not get a good 3d print like calibration or filament humidity, all things you have to learn to get good results.

video_title: How Good is this Thing? Snapmaker 2.0 Laser Module Review
comment_text: This is expensive shit, like the previous snapmakers.

video_title: How Good is this Thing? Snapmaker 2.0 Laser Module Review
comment_text:
I have one. I hate it, and I truly wish I had bought a D1, cheap CNC, and upgraded a few of my enders. Would have saved me a lot of time and money. 

So within a week of opening the machine, I reached out to Snapmaker for support concerning the laser function. Turns out the guy I got stuck with didn't know what he was talking about. He told me it was broken, and I was then jacked around for 3 months before they stopped replying at all. 3 months later (6 months in total) They reach back out to me concerning a negative review I left on a third party site.  I used their contact to start trying to get help from them again, only to find out the problem I originally had is a limitation of the machine itself. Camera capture cannot accurately capture tall items  (3-4" tall) for engraving. It just cuts out massive sections of the image. So 6 months, countless hours of time, and countless materials wasted trying to fix a machine that they said was broken... that wasn't. 

They also removed my negative review from their site, and tried to bribe me into taking down my third party site review. 

I did end up getting a 50% refund, but that was because I was prepared to dispute the charges with Paypal. It's an ok, non upgradeable 3D printer. It's not a Prusa, or even an Ender. Haven't had a chance to play with the CNC yet, as the machine is noisy enough on its own. 

My review stands, and I'll continue to tell everyone about my experiences. The machine is meh, and the support is crap.

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text:
Hi Brandon, I recently picked up the Neje A40640 and have been working on calibrating it for a few weeks - I'm a total n00b and really appreciate your videos!

When digging a bit deeper into the reference documentation - I noticed that this module has a variable focal distance - the lens actually rotates. In the Neje wiki documentation I've found that they recommend setting it at a focal distance of about 33mm for engraving and about 55mm for cutting (18mm ply?!?).  You have to unscrew the lens about 7 full rotations from it's fully 'closed' or seated position against the upper housing for engraving but it definitely produces a finer spot. 

My USB microscope doesn't have a measurement tool but from my very rough estimate, it looks like I can get a line width of around .12 when setup for the 'engraving'  focal distance.

I'm sure folks would appreciate your more seasoned look at it - especially as you call it out as having a bigger dot width, which may not be entirely accurate given the configuration options. 

I hope this observation comes across in the most positive light,  I really appreciate all videos and your calibration methods - super helpful for someone new to the technology! Keep up the great work!!

video_title: My Favorite Laser Just Got Better! - xTool D1 Upgrades
comment_text: I designed and 3D printed an air assist for my Ortur LaserMaster Pro.  It makes all the difference in the world in how it cuts. What used to take 9 passes now only takes 3 and much cleaner cut without all the smoke. I am using a Harbor Freight airbrush compressor for the air supply with no regulator. The hole in the nozzle where the laser and air comes through is about 1.5mm in diameter and maybe about 3mm above the focal point so the stream of air is getting right into the cut.

video_title: Can This Laser Beat the Competition? Sculpfun S9 Laser Review
comment_text: Im still using my eleksmaker laser. Noticed it uses 2 stepper motors to drive the y axis compared to this sculpfun which has the one stepper motor and the long shaft to the other side. Considering recreating this on mine and reusing that extra stepper for a z axis or possibly rotary attachment! Also 3d printing an air assist that uses a small aquarium pump!

video_title: Can This Laser Beat the Competition? Sculpfun S9 Laser Review
comment_text: Soo I have an Atomstack A5pro which is about the same power 5,5W. These diode laser are great TOYS yes toys... they are great sweet toys to learn laser cutting to use Lightburn but they are absolutely unusable to anything serious. After half year I bought a 50W CO2 laser and the difference is DAY and NIGHT. If you want to cut out anything complicated with a diode laser you have to wait 2-3 hours... the CO2 is exactly 10X faster which is a LOT. Without air assist and what is even more important without smoke sucking!!!!  People cannot imagine how much smoke these machines generate, you cannot stay in the same room if you are cutting wood or plastic for longer times..... Soo please people don't believe anybody if you really want to cut than save up for a CO2 machine. (Yes I know it cost 6-7X more but it worth it) These diode lasers are a waist of money... and no they will not be stronger the two diode versions are quite expensive with 10W makes the CO2 almost cheap. Only one thing which is slightly better with the diode laser is the the kerf (cutting width) is slightly smaller (but also not circular but like rectangle). Think long term go with CO2...

video_title: This Laser Can Engrave METAL!  -  OMTech 20W Fiber Laser Review
comment_text: In a fiber laser, the laser *is* the fiber, in the sense that they dope it to make it have optical gain. They might pump it with a diode laser, but it's not just a bunch of diode lasers.
